Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Continued Study of Physical Properties of the WAIS Divide Deep Core
Award.AbstractNarration:
1043528/Alley

This award supports a project to complete the physical-properties studies of the WAIS Divide deep ice core, now being collected in West Antarctica. Ongoing work funded by NSF, under a grant that is ending, has produced visible stratigraphy dating, inspection of the core for any melt layers, volcanic horizons, flow disturbances or other features, analysis of bubble number-densities allowing reconstruction of a two-millennial cooling trend in the latter Holocene at the site, characterization of other bubble characteristics (size, etc.), density studies, characterization of snow-surface changes at the site, preliminary c-axis studies, and more. The current proposal seeks to complete this work, once the rest of the core is recovered. The intellectual merit of the proposed activity starts with quality assurance for the core, by visual detection of any evidence of flow disturbances that would disrupt the integrity of the climate record. Inspection will also reveal any melt layers, volcanic horizons, etc. Annual-layer dating will be conducted; thus far, the visible strata have not been as useful as some other indicators, but the possibility (based on experience in Greenland) that visible examination will allow detection of thinner annual layers than other techniques motivates the effort. Bubble number-density will be used to reconstruct temperature changes through the rest of the bubbly part of the core, providing important paleoclimatic data for earlier parts of the Holocene. Coordinated interpretation of c-axis fabrics, grain sizes and shapes, and bubble characteristics will be used to learn about the history of ice flow, the processes of ice flow, and the softness of the ice for additional deformation. Analysis of surface data already collected will improve interpretation of the layering of the core. It is possible that the annual-layer dating will not be sufficiently successful, and that the core will be undisturbed with no melt layers; if so, then these efforts will not yield major publications. However, success of the other efforts should produce improved understanding of the history and stability of the ice sheet, and key processes controlling these, and the quality assurance provided by the visual examination is important for the project as a whole. The broader impacts of the proposed activity include education of a PhD student and multiple undergraduates, and research opportunities for a junior faculty member at an undergraduate institution. The proposed activity will help support an especially vigorous education and outreach effort providing undergraduate instruction for over 1000 students per year, reaching thousands more citizens and many policymakers, and preparing educational materials used at many levels.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Collaborative Research: Continued Study of Physical Properties of the WAIS Divide Deep Core

NSF OPP 1043528, R.B. Alley and D.E. Voigt

06/01/11-05/31/16

Project Outcomes Report

 

Our research team provided quality assurance for the highly successful WAIS Divide Deep Ice Core Project, characterized the physical properties of the core to aid in understanding ice flow and ice-sheet stability, helped reconstruct climate history, and conducted a vigorous program of education and outreach, thus contributing to public understanding and technical knowledge while generating professional publications and publicly archived data. In this brief Outcomes report, we summarize the Intellectual Merit and then the Broader Impacts of the completed project.

 

Intellectual Merit.

 

Field work over multiple seasons showed that changing weather patterns leave a recognizable signature in the snow and firn at the site, including frequently producing thin, nearly impermeable crusts.  The resulting layering can be traced through the firn into the ice, and used to help identify annual layers, although identification of annual layers is done more easily with chemical and electrical signals than with visible inspection.  The crusts do not notably disturb the ice-core gas record, because they do not involve large quantities of refrozen meltwater that might contain dissolved gases, and they develop polygonal cracks during near-surface nighttime cooling that ventilate the firn beneath. Crusts form more commonly in summer but can be produced at any time of year; changes in frequency of crust occurrence with time may provide information on the frequency of the meteorological conditions that produce crusts.

 

The history of flow is recorded in the c-axis fabric of the ice (Figure 19 from Fitzpatrick and others, 2014), with c-axes first rotating towards a vertical plane and then toward the vertical, before becoming more scattered in the deepest, warmest ice in response to recrystallization. Large disturbances that could disrupt the climate record of the ice core were absent, as shown by visible examination and c-axis fabrics, likely at least in part because recrystallization was rapid enough to remove the anisotropic structures from grain-scale interactions that lead to folding or other disturbances at some sites.  Impurities affect grain growth and probably other processes, but not greatly, so relations for firn densification and grain growth can be used without explicitly accounting for impurity effects.

 

Bubble number-density can be measured reliably, and changes coherently with depth. Estimated paleotemperatures calculated from the bubble number-density and reconstructed accumulation are similar to independent estimates from the isotopic composition of the ice at the site. Slight elongation of bubbles may serve as a useful strain indicator to help understand grain-scale deformation processes.

 

Our collaboration contributed to important paleoclimatic studies documenting the Antarctic response to global environmental change, with important implications for understanding of climate processes.

 

Data sets have been deposited at the National Snow and Ice Data Center including;

 

  • C-axis Fabric from Physical Properties Samples of the WAIS Divide Ice Core; Voigt, Alley and Fitzpatrick.
  • Bubble Number-density Data and Modeled Paleoclimates; Alley and Fegyveresi.
  • Grain Size Full Population Dataset from WDC06A Core; Fitzpatrick and Cravens.
  • WAIS Divide Ice Core Vertical Thin Section Low-resolution Digital Imagery; Fizpatrick and Cravens
